reviewText: They sure don't make 'em like this anymore. "Silent Night, Deadly Night" is one of the last out of the gate during the early '80s slasher wave, and it stirred up enough controversy that theaters were picketed for portraying Santa as a psycho. While the film is obviously cheaply made, you have to give it credit for taking the time to develop the characters, especially Billy, who is not a carbon copy, one-note lunatic; one can see why his mind snaps, and that makes the following carnage all the more unsettling. Featuring some truly original murder sequences---especially the sleigh ride decapitation and the antler impalement---this one is hard to forget. On the other side of the door comes the lame sequel, with over 40 minutes of recycled footage from Part 1. The new footage looks like it was filmed with a kiddie camcorder. Especially laughable in the sequel is the scene where the woman thanks the psycho for running over her seedy boyfriend!  Still, the DVD is worth getting for the above average first entry, with a crisp, clear resolution and some interesting extras (but beware of the rambling audio commentary from director Charles Sellier Jr.).

reviewText: A lot of folks believe that stern discipline builds character in a young person...not so much here.  Apparently, if the mother superior has a penchant for beating your butt like a sideshow freak, you will grow up to dress as jolly ol' Saint Nick and go on a killin' spree. (Seems legit)  These flicks are like Neil Diamond..you'll either love 'em or hate 'em. I'm a few quarts low, so I'm on the love side of the fence.  As per most movies..part 2 is not the cinematic masterpiece you've dreamed of, but it works for me. Enjoy the gore..laugh..repeat.

reviewText: I remember the big controversy back when SILENT NIGHT / DEADLY NIGHT hit the theatres. MAHS (Mothers Against Homicidal Santas) attacked the movie mercilessly, many (most) of the mad-mums never even having seen it! The story grew and became legend. After watching SN / DN a few minutes ago, it's difficult to understand all the hubbub it created. Yes, there's a killer-claus. Yes, he goes on a murderous rampage at christmas time. No, it's not any more graphic or outrageous than any of the other holiday-horror movies that obviously inspired it. I liked it a lot actually! As far as x-mas horror films go, SN / DN is somewhere between DON'T OPEN 'TIL CHRISTMAS and CHRISTMAS EVIL. It's no BLACK CHRISTMAS by any means, but it ain't bad! Besides, it even has Linnea Quigley (Return Of The Living Dead, Night Of The Demons, Graduation Day) as a disrobed victim! My oh my, that gal just can't keep those clothes on, not even in December! So, settle down for a long winter's evening of jingle kills! As for SILENT NIGHT / DEADLY NIGHT PT. 2, let's just say it's a pile of yellow snow. Mostly flashbacks of the first movie, although the last 15 minutes are pretty good!...

reviewText: It is so funny upon thinking about it that Silent Night, Deadly Night has gained such a reputation as being a film that is so gory, so offensive, that it was banned in many places for years.  Honestly, the only reason the film was banned and the only reason parents had problems with the films was the fact that the TV commercials were making little kids terrified of Santa.  This movie isn't any more gory or violent than it's holiday-themed predecessors such as Friday the 13th and Halloween.  It's just that fact that it deals with such a "sacred subject" as Santa that upsets people.Frankly both of these movies aren't even really that great.  Anchor Bay has released the first film unrated with extra gore spliced in, making it the most complete edition ever released.  I can honestly say that I did not find any of the added footage any more offensive or disturbing than the original.  The fact that these films (especially the first one) take themselves so seriously is the most offensive thing of all.Anchor Bay has released these films on a two-sided DVD and each movie has it's own small amount of special features, including trailers, interviews, and a commentary track.  The video quality is decent on both films.  The "uncut" footage that was spliced into the first film from a different print looks much rougher and more washed out than the rest of the film, however I did not find it too distracting.  The mono audio is sufficient for what it is.  No technical problems really.If you are looking for a good holiday movie, buy "It's a Wonderful Life."  If that's not available, get "Mr. Magoo's Christmas Carol."  If Christmas cheer is what you are after, these are perfect.  If you want to see a psycho in a Santa suit hack people up, get the Silent Night Deadly Night double feature.  Just don't expect it to instill the Christmas spirit into your family.

reviewText: Ah, SILENT NIGHT DEADLY NIGHT, that little slasher movie that pissed off a lot of critics and PTA groups in half the nation (it was pulled before it reached the West Coast) since the killer was dressed as Santa. Incidentally, it's easy to see why it was so controviersial, <PUNISH!> since the story is told from the point-of-view of the killer and it focuses on the factors that cause his murderous rampage. <NAUGHTY!> Gee, didn't producer Ira Richard Barmak or TriStar Pictures learn anything from the brouhaha that surrounded MANIAC (an excellent movie)? Didn't they realize that <PUNISH!> any horror movie where the murderer is the main character and not just a plot device, especially when the movie involves a sacred holiday (it worked for the excellent BLACK CHRISTMAS), <NAUGHTY!> will incur the wrath of sensitive moviegoers? (Hello, parents, it WAS rated R anyway; kids wouldn't be able to see it anyway, although those TV spots must have been scary to unwary kids.) I guess they didn't, and God bless 'em for that! Anyway, this is the good stuff here; we get an uncut presentation (with deleted scenes from another source; as with DEEP RED-THE DIRECTOR'S CUT, once you get used to the switches in quality (DEEP RED's restored scenes were in Italian only), it's a great ride), plus a telephone interview with director Charles E. Sellier, Jr., who expresses interesting and thoughtful opinions of the film and the controversy surrounding it.But I myself prefer the hilarious sequel <PUNISH!>, which seems to piss off all the horror purists out there, especially fans of the original. Hello! This is SUPPOSED to be a comedy (along the lines of EVIL DEAD 2, which came out in the same year), meaning NOT TO BE TAKEN SERIOUSLY! <NAUGHTY!> But anyway, I think that the editing of footage from the original was pretty cool at times, especially <PUNISH!> when it jumps from old scene to new scene. For example, when we see the scene where Mother Superior is belting Billy, it cuts between that and Ricky (Eric Freeman, who was awesome) recalling it (<Whip!> She <Whip!> was <Whip!> naughty.); I thought that was too cool. Among other things, the funniest scenes are when Ricky impales a loan shark on an umbrella and opens it, as well as Ricky's shooting spree (hence the title of this article). The commentary by the director/editor/writer, the other writer, and actor James Newman (the psychologist) enhances the humor of the movie; <NAUGHTY!> I laughed right along with them and I am glad they feel the same way that I, and a few other viewers, feel.Anchor Bay did right by the fans of these two movies by putting them on a flipper disc. <PUNISH! NAUGHTY! PUNISH! NAUGHTY!> The supplemental material on both movies as mentioned above alone is worth the retail price! So don't be NAUGHTY!; go out and see these lost gems of the slasher wave, becasuse <PUNISH!> in the words of the grandfather in the first film, "Christmas Eve is the scariest damn night of the year!"
Title: N/A

reviewText: Ah yes, it's the film that brought the public masses into a furor not seen since The Last Temptation of Christ!  It seems that the image of Santa with an axe, lobbing off heads and impaling topless B-movie queens onto antlers doesn't bring out tidings of comfort and joy.  But as we all know, 99% of the protesters never saw the movie, so was the hulabaloo worth it?SNDN starts off with a bang, as a poor little boy has one helluva Xmas eve.  After being mentally traumatized by his senile grandfather who informs him that Santa punishes naughty kids, he then sees his father killed and mother raped by a deranged lunatic dressed up as Saint Nick.Cut to several years later, and our hero is now a mentally unstable teenager, working in a store where he is forced to assume the role of, surprise surprise, Santa Claus.  With his fragile sanity on the wain, he breaks down and assumes the role of the evil Santa that massacred his parents, extracting a bloody demise on all the "naughty" people.It's tasteless, but SNDN is successful on several levels.  The film contains a good amount of violence with some original killings (big thumbs up for Linnea Quigley!).  Accidental humor also matches the tacky feel of the film (giving a bloody boxcutter to a "good" girl, Grandpa's hilarious speech about Santa).  The concept of an evil Santa and/or murder on the Xmas holidays has been done before and done better (check out Black Christmas, THE quintessential holiday horror movie).  It's a guilty pleasure movie, certainly not the coming of the anti-Christ that the protestors painted it to be.  4 Stars.SNDN2- you could use this movie as a coaster for your drink.  Mostly made up of flashbacks of the first SNDN, combined with one of the worst acting jobs I've ever seen- Ricky makes Sofia Coppolla look like Meryl Streep.  If you must watch part 2, you can spend the time making a game out of how many times it looks like Ricky's eyebrows are going to fly off his face whenever he delivers a line.  Naughty boys and girls should be forced to watch SNDN2, but that's just cruel punishment. 0 Stars.Remember, "You see Santa Claus tonight you better run, boy!"
summary: HO HO HO and HA HA HA

reviewText: Not exactly two for the price of one as the second feature (Silent Night Deadly Night part 2) is just the first film condensed and sanitized, commented on by the younger brother of the killer in the first film.  Technically, there's just one and a half movies offered here.It's difficult to imagine these movies were controversial when first released.  By today's standards, they are quite tame.  I liked the first entry best; at least it got into the spirit of the genre, the second installment wastes time going over old ground before getting to the younger brother's killing spree.  The best that can be said about the younger brother is that he was certainly jolly and enjoyed his work.From this movie, I learned how to make a psychopath.  Take equal parts the fear of a creepy grandfather, a murderer wearing a Santa suit, and add one evil mother superior with a penchant for discipline/punishment/torture.  Presto, a goody-goody stock boy becomes an ax wielding murderer on a rampage (thank goodness the store thoughtfully provided his suit and beard......not to mention the ax).I'm keeping this for the first movie; the second movie was tolerated only by fast-forwarding through most of it, until I got to the new material, which was very late in coming.

reviewText: Anyone who knows me or has read my articles for the last couple of years knows my love of Santa Claus slasher films. Every year a couple of my buddies and I get together and watch these exquisite gems. I can almost guarantee you I've seen the movie if it has anything to do with a crazy guy dressed up in Jolly Ole Saint Nick's duds while taking an axe to both the naughty and nice. "Christmas Evil?" Seen it. "Santa's Slay?" Seen it. "Sint?" Seen it. That episode of "Tales from the Crypt" starring Dr. Giggles dressed up as Kris Kringle? Seen it.Two movies I'd only seen in an edited form called were recently released by Anchor Bay in the form of "Silent Night, Deadly Night Christmas Survival Double Feature." "Silent Night, Deadly Night" and "Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2" both had condensed versions in the Christmas event "Horror Remix: You Better Watch Out" which is played annually at Studio Movie Grill's nationwide. After viewing two 90-minute films cut down into one 30-minute section made me curious to see what was left on the cutting room floor by "Horror Remix" editors.First off, an introduction to the "Silent Night, Deadly Night" series must be given to those uneducated. The first film centers on little Billy, who sees his parents brutally murdered by a man in a Santa Claus costume one fateful Christmas Eve. After spending time in an abusive Catholic Boy's Home, he is given a job at a toy store.Everything goes fine until images of Saint Nick start popping up in the store. He suddenly begins having mental breakdowns at work. Things only get worse when he's asked by his boss to don a Santa suit and greet children. The sight of himself in the outfit drives him over the edge. Billy decides it's time to start punishing all the naughty folks he comes across.The second movie spends about 45-minutes of its 88-minute running time rehashing old footage from the first one. 60-minutes of this has Billy's brother, Ricky, telling a psychiatrist how he was affected by his parent's death and watching his sibling abused at the hands of Mother Superior at the Boy's Home.After telling the story, he escapes from prison and goes on one of the most hilarious killing sprees caught on film. Will someone find a way to stop him before he reaches Mother Superior and punishes her for being naughty?"Silent Night, Deadly Night" is one of those films that I hate to say is so bad it's good. It genuinely tries to explore what makes people go crazy. You feel sorry for little Billy more and more throughout the film. No matter how it ultimately turned out, you can sense that director Charles E. Sellier, Jr. was trying to have a good time making a shocking movie with some interesting social commentary."Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2" is nothing but so bad it's good. Most of Eric Freeman's acting is done with his eyebrows. This begs the question, "How can someone overact using their eyebrows?" Believe me when I say it can be done.It's easy to get through "Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2" if you just fast forward through all the scenes from the first film. You're left with about 45 minutes of wonderfully bad dialogue and a few madcap slayings you'll never forget. Just don't mistakenly skip through any of the parts in the room where the psychiatrist and Ricky are talking. There are some funny exchanges between the two of them you won't want to miss.Special features for "Silent Night, Deadly Night" include an audio interview with director Charles E. Sellier, Jr. There's also a poster and still gallery and "Santa's Stocking of Outrage," which features negative reactions from notable personalities and reviewers about the movie when it first came out.Bonus material for "Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2" consist of audio commentary with writer / director Lee Harry, writer Joseph H. Earle and actor James Newman. It also features a theatrical trailer, poster and still gallery, and access to the original screenplay on DVD-ROM.Anchor Bay's "Silent Night, Deadly Night Christmas Survival Double Feature" delivers the best of both worlds. You get one movie that wants and deserves to be taken seriously to an extent and another that is just plain silly and delivers a gory good time for those with an appetite for black humor and murderous Santas. It's recommended viewing for slasher fans looking for a fun way to celebrate the season.
summary: DVD Review: "Silent Night, Deadly Night Christmas Survival Double Feature"

reviewText: I have wanted to see this for years(the first one at least).  I was only a child when this made in 1984.  I had read reviews for this so I more/less knew what to expect.  This is your typical homicidal maniac slasher movie but with a yuletide twist.  It has ludacris violence and a good amount of nudity.  When I did watch it in addition to the film itself I saw the toy store scenes.  Those toys took me down memory lane.  I remember many of those(Squirt squirt  squirt the Animals, a Smurfs puzzle, Java the hut, and a Miss Piggy puppet).  They were many of the same toys I had gotten for Xmas in 1984.  Funny how I felt happy from seeing those toys again.As far as the Second one:  I have not watched it yet so I can't comment.In all if you like a cheesey slasher movie this is a cult classic

reviewText: SILENT NIGHT DEADLY NIGHT was a film I avoided for a long time (15 years or so) because the hype is such that it comes off as an intimidating film.  It's supposed to be notoriously gory and in bad taste or seen as a joke of a movie, but it's not. In fact the story is smart, the writing is unexpectedly decent and it really is kind of impressive upon first watch. The problem is that the film is only slightly disjointed and the viewer may have a hard time believing Billy's motive as the killer.It's the notorious slasher movie that pissed off a lot of critics (including Siskel and Ebert) and parents groups in the U.S. upon its release in 1984 (though it was pulled before it reached the West Coast) because the killer was dressed as Santa Clause. It would have maybe been slightly better if Billy actually wore the fake Santa beard correctly and so much of his abusive back story wasn't divulged (mysterious horror villains are scarier, after all). It is notable for the ax scene in the house (they used a real ax). Overall, an entertaining slasher, and a must see at least once, but you can decide if it's right for your collection. Not essential.The hilariously bad sequel which seems to piss off all the slasher purists out there, especially fans of the original, can be skipped.

reviewText: Lilyan Chauvin delivers an Oscar-winning performance as the control freak, Mother Superior, in "Silent Night, Deadly Night."  I hated Mother Superior with a passion.  She was very cruel, sadistic and self-righteous and very instrumental in causing Billy to become insane and "punish" all sinners.  Though not on a par with the classic "Black Christmas" of 1974, "Silent Night, Deadly Night" is an enjoyable entry in the Christmas holiday slasher fare.  Anchor Bay did an excellent job of presenting this movie in its original uncut version.  The theatrical version nearly cut out ten minutes from the beginning, which was instrumental in explaining Billy's fear that Santa Claus would punish him.  The additional footage showed the killer Santa Claus robbing a convenience store and shooting dead the attendant; it also shows Billy's visit with his grandfather in the insane asylum.The movie has a high body count and the action is well paced.  However, the acting could've been better.  The actor chosen to play Billy was too pretty.  When he was wearing the Santa Claus suit, he looked very feminine - almost like a man in drag.  I wish Billy could've killed Mother Superior in the end but he failed.  Alas, in the sequel, his bodybuilding brother, Ricky, has the honor of avenging his brother's death."Silent Night, Deadly Night Part 2" chronicles how Ricky becomes insane and follows in his brother's deadly footsteps.  Approximately one-third of the movie consists of flashbacks taken directly from the first "Silent Night, Deadly Night."  This would've been okay if it had been years since seeing the first movie; however, since it was a double feature, the flashbacks were tiresome.  Yes, the acting, dialogue, and death sequences are inferior to those in the original.  However, most important is the fact that Ricky does avenge his brother's death and Mother Superior receives her due reward for torturing innocent, young orphans.The Anchor Bay double feature is far superior to that of the one that was recently released by the same company which only has the original "Silent Night, Deadly Night."  The two movies should be watched together.  Because I consider Part 2 to be a large bonus, I am giving Anchor Bay's double feature five stars.  Anchor Bay should consider re-releasing more of its double features as double features rather than splitting them up and selling them separately.
summary: Thank You, Ricky, For Killing Mother Superior

reviewText: I love these two movies. Yes, the quality sucks... yes, the acting sucks... and yes, the story sucks. But with classic scenes like a deranged Santa chopping the head off a snowman, how can you NOT love SNDN? What blows my mind is how vilified this movie was when it first came out. Those of you old enough to remember will recall the outcry over the release of this movie, the boycotts, the press... well, when you see it you'll wonder "why was there such an uproar?" Come ON, people. The SNDN franchise is so completely ridiculous it's incredible how seriously some people took it. So, watch it with the same mindset I did: just good, clean, ridiculous fun. You'll love it.

reviewText: HAHAHAHAHA!!!  I'm glad that Anchor Bay released or re-released this set on DVD.  Its hard to keep track of what version is in what format and which one is the unaffordable, out of print copy and blah blah blah.  Anyways, I got this copy for a cheap price and couldn't be happier.  You get two discs!  You get the original Silent Night, Deadly Night, uncut in its full antler piercing glory.  And you get the hilarious Part 2, which is the only sequel worth getting in this series.  Of course, the first film is a holiday favorite of mines and I've seen it a dozen times.  But Silent Night Deadly Night 2 is a classic.  How can you beat a film that looks like a few drunken college kids, got together and spliced it with the first movie?  Its so phenomenally bad that I can't stop watching it.  The acting is borderline retarded, the production value looks like someone sold their father's oldsmobile to fund the film and of course, "GARBAGE DAY!!"  The first half of the movie is from part 1, in the second half, you see young "Ricky" go from little kid, to different little kid, to small guy with two toned hair who looks older then the adult Ricky then finally you see the eyebrow fluttering, buffed out Ricky.  In another great scene you see Ricky in a movie theatre watching Silent Night, Deadly Night with his girlfriend, HILARIOUS!  Later you see him stopped by a cop who looks like Barney Fife's nephew and of course, GARBAGE DAY!!  This is the greatest comedy ever made!
summary: GARBAGE DAY SHOULD BE A HOLIDAY

reviewText: In "Silent Night Deadly Night" it is the story of a former child named Billy who was going with his family to see his grandpa at a mental institute in Utah, later his grandpa tells him that Santa Claus will punish him if he has been bad then later his parents are murdered by a robber in a Santa Claus outfit as 4 years later he is at a orphaned with his brother run by nuns especially Mother Superior who has a thing to punish bad kids especially the traumatized Billy. 10 years later he has grown up and he's gotten a job at a local toy store where he finds it a great job for 3 months until when Christmas time hits, he is assigned to be the store's Santa Claus then at Christmas Eve he suddenly snaps and goes on a killing spree. Then followed by "Part 2" is 15 years after Billy was killed, Ricky has grown up and is in a mental institute where he is interrogated by a detective who wants to know his background and history. He tells him his long history from infancy to his adulthood, after the time when the killer Santa came to the orphanage then it was closed down as Ricky has finally gotten a family and has grew up with them but as an adult he still has bad memories that can trigger to his killing of naughty people and even wants to kill retired head nun Mother Superior.The original movie was one of the most controversial, disturbing, sleaziest and shocking horror movies of it's time! in fact when the movie came out in november of 1984 parent groups protested the movie cause they disapprove of the idea of Santa Claus as a mass murderer then the studio Tri-Star pictures decided to have the film pulled out of theaters within three weeks. The movie later came on video in a uncut unrated version with scenes of gore trimmed for the "R" rated Tri-Star theatrical out to avoid an "X" rating, the sequel's not too bad at all but very enjoyable even though in the first half of Ricky's memories are clips from the original movie then to his growing up perioid where he becomes a murderer and there's some creative kills like putting spark plugs on a guy's tounge then shocking their head until the eyes explode, not as good as the cult original flick but enjoyable.This DVD has good picture and sound quality! the extras are very nice like an audio interview with the director of the first movie  Charlie E. Sellier Jr, Santa's Gallery of Outrage with the bad reviews and angry letters from parents, audio commentary ( on part 2 only), DVD-Rom screenplay ( on part 2 only), trailer to "Silent Night 2" and poster-and-still galleries for parts 1 & 2.Also recommended: "The Shining", "Halloween series", "Friday The 13th series", "High Tension", " Henry: Portrait of a Serial Killer", "Silence of the Lambs", "Scream", "Maniac ( 1980)", "Sleepaway Camp"," The Prowler", "I Spit on Your Grave", " A Clockwork Orange", " The Hills Have Eyes ( 1978 and 2006)", " Urban Legend", " My Blood Valentine", " Happy Birthday to Me", " Christmas Evil", " Prom Night", " Bad Santa", Nightmare on Elm Street", "Freddy Vs. Jason", " Perfect Blue", " Tales from The Crypt ( 1972)", " Driller Killer", " House of 1000 Corpses", " The Devil's Rejects", "Mother's Day", "Hell Night", "Bloody Birthday", " Gremlins", " Cape Fear", " The Toolbox Murders ( 1978 and 2004)", "Ichi The Killer", "Cry Wolf",  "Terror Train", " The New York Ripper", " Wrong Turn", "Wolf Creek", "Hostel", and " Psycho ( 1960)".
summary: Two very good horror shockers on DVD!
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you've read any of my other reviews, which I'm sure you have because who doesn't like to sit and look through pages and pages of peoples opinions on movies, you'll know that I love horror movies. It's not that I sit around in black make-up and listen to slayer while sacrificing my cat over a pentigram shaped candle display, I just like to be scared.If there is one thing I know, when someone writes a review about a movie, they either hated it or loved it. I've been trying, while I'm waiting for my job to come through, to write a few reviews on movies that I feel give the clear picture of the movie. People have given Silent Night Deadly Night or (SNDN) a pretty harsh bashing so I'm here to give you horror buffs a little more real review.The first thing I always look for in a horror movie is, does it look well made, and is the acting of a better than average quality. When I say well made I mean does it look like it was shot in 1972 even though the movie came out in 1988. Directors make all the difference in this. SNDN looks well made. It doesn't look cheap, and the picture is clear and sharp. The camera work is done very well. The acting is pretty good to for a horror movie. It has it's cheesy moments but for the most part it is good. The only acting problem is how the main character keeps yelling naughty towards the end of the picture. After he says it for the tenth time you get the point, but they keep it going which kindof turned me off at the end.The next thing I look for is, are the death scenes realistic and believable. This movie does an excellent job in this. The death scenes all look very well done, and all of them could have really happened. I dont' think anything turns me off to a movie more when you see a completely outrageous and elaborate death scene, that leaves you saying..... yeah right.The only complaint I have is the girl on the elk antlers. I don't know about you, but I have experience with drywall and screws in drywall and I don't think that a mounted elk-head would be strong enough to hold up a woman. However, I heard this was a spur of the moment death sequence they came up with, so you gotta give them a little slack.The last thing I look for in a horror movie is the ending. You spend an hour and a half watching a movie, and if the ending is below par the movie isn't as good.  I think that the best example of this is Nightmare on Elm Street I. If you've seen the film you know what I mean. The ending for SNDN is pretty good. It's predictable but it's what you want to happen while your watching the movie.The best thing about SNDN is the whole backstory. Most horror movies give you ten minutes of backstory and then on to the killing. They don't take time to develop the plot. This movie is great because it shows you why the killer is the way he is. He isn't some axe welding crazy person, he's a real person, and you feel for him. Once he goes on his rampage you understand why he is doing what he is doing.If you love horror movies, buy the DVD. It's a classic horror filmed that started a huge uproar, which only lead to its success. Part 2 is absolutely awful, so don't even bother watching it. In fact why don't you take a screwdriver and just scratch that side of the DVD up (ha). But part one has all the key elements of a horror movie, which makes a pretty decent slasher.
summary: SILENT NIGHT DEADLY NIGHT.... DEAD ON TARGET

reviewText: This movie is amazing it is a B movie but a really good one. The story involves a little boy who watches his parents brutally married by a man dressed as Santa who violates and kills his mom. The boy is always haunted by Christmas and expecially Santa clause. This is one of the most original horror movies and one of the only with Santa as an axe wielding psycho. When the boy grows older you think he is fine and over the horror of the night but in all reality he's about to loose it. Without giving away to much he becomes Santa and begins to "punish" people who are "naughty" I loved this movie. It was great fun and original. And rather gory for an 80's horror movie I can see why it was banned back in the day. If you like my bloody valentine (original) you will enjoy this. :)

reviewText: Silent Night Deadly Night really caused a ruckous when it was originally released, but remember the golden rule, there is no such thing as bad publicity. All the bad hype it was getting actually drew more people to the film. It worked on me, I admit. I had to see the film that caused so much commotion. I ended up really disappointed. Although not a bad concept for a horror film, it's just executed poorly. Poor directing, editing, acting. This film might have turned out alright if it has some actual talent behind the camera (such as John Carpenter or Wes Craven). Even though the film isn't all that good, Anchor Bay does a great job bringing it to DVD. This time it is FULLY uncut for the first time. Sadly the cut portions that were added back in the film are of poorer picture quality than of the original film, but Anchor Bay did the best they could to get the cut scenes to match the original material. What can I say about Silent Night Deadly Night Part 2, it is just terrible. At least the original SNDN had an original story, the second film is 45 minutes of flashbacks from the first film and 40 minutes of new material. Talk about a cheap trick to get people into the theaters. The director even admits it in the commontary! No wonder they shoved it on the same disc as SNDN1, because there is no way they could sell it seperatly. I still can't believe there were even 3 more sequels! Horror fans who are curious, rent this film first. If you like the film for whatever reason, you won't be disappointed by this DVD release.
summary: Weak film not worth all the hype

reviewText: Part 1Silent Night, Deadly Night is an outright awesome B movie horror that stands out from the other Christmas murder films of that era, let alone horror films in general, and is truly my all-time favorite horror film.  This controversial 1984 film received more attention due to its content around the religious holiday of Christmas, than some of the graphic and creative preferred methods of dispatching death dealt upon those deemed naughty by the twisted and sick Santa.  Protests and picket signs were held across the nation and hate filled letters towards this shining piece of horror cinema were published in numerous newspapers.  This led to an eventual pulling of the film from theaters across the country, but its popularity would steadily reach cult status once it was released on VHS tape to the multitude of macabre masses.  I personally first gazed upon this golden chunk of film at the age of six (yes, my mother was a big fan of horror and this was passed down to me... no, I did not end up a serial killer).The term so bad its good may be cliché, but it sticks to this movie like the dried incrusted crimson on the sharp edge of Santa's ax of choice.  As bad as the film may be at times, it is still a step above Trauma Film's impressive list of low budget oddities or Full Moon's creative crown jewel, Puppet Master.  This movie truly holds up even to this day; with its dated hair styles, fashion, and effects.  I cannot forget to mention the corny holiday music that ends up growing on you after repeated viewings (Warm Side of the Store and Merry Christmas Baby in particular).  It totally outdoes the current remake from 2012, Silent Night, shaming it instantly to the bargain bins and bottom shelves of discount stores forever.  (Check out my review on it).Silent Night (Blu-ray + DVD)Decent writing actually contributes to surprising amounts of versatility to the main character of Billy Chapman; making him more interesting and even garnered some sympathy for the Kris Kringle killer.  Witnessing the murder of his family, massacred by a deranged killer dressed as Saint Nick is what greatly contributed to his unbalanced mind and outlook on life.  Ho ho ho!  This story was further fleshed out and built upon by Billy and his little brother Ricky being raised in a Catholic orphanage in rural Utah.  The cold hearted and wicked Mother Superior, who ran the orphanage with an iron fist, clenching a rosary, remorselessly dished out unlimited abuse upon the young Billy.  The repeated physical and mental anguish by Mother Superior contributed loads of further torment to his fragile psyche.  When Billy turns 16 his life is somewhat stabilized and he goes to work at a toy store for Mr. Sims with the help of Sister Margaret. He works hard (in a classic montage) and shyly fawns over his co-worker, Pamela (check out He-man's Castle Greyskull, G.I. Joe figures, Return of the Jedi's Jabba the Hut, and Poochy sitting on the shelves). Even with a momentary bit of calm Billy's destiny was guaranteed to unfold and he would finally snap.  All it took was a red and white suit and the ignorance of a cocky A-hole to kick off the mayhem with a festive string of lights...  Yes, some clear predictability is obvious, but there are several plot twists to keep you on your toes throughout and a steady pace moves the picture along the first three quarters, but begins to falter once the crescendo of the sledding scene hits you full force.  Woooo!  Woooo!  Yeah! Woooo!The acting overall is better than you would expect, but some bad acting prevails and actually adds to the film.  There is an interesting line up of 1980's character actors that put in decent performances and you may recognize a few of them.  Billy, the tortured boy and future grizzly killer was played by the relatively unknown, Robert Brain Wilson.  He does a pretty good job as the shy and shell shocked teen and shines as the Santa suited slayer of the naughty. Punish!  His nutty and senile Grandpa is played by, Will Hare (Enter the Ninja, Back to the Future), in the movie's introductionary scenes.  He eerily instills to his grandson Billy a disturbing twisted take on what happens to those that have been naughty on Christmas Eve.  Naughty!  The dopey store manager, Mr. Sims, played by, Britt Leach (Weird Science, The Great Outdoors) was really done well as a likeable and nave father figure to the film's main character, Billy.  Another fine example is B movie scream queen, Linnea Quigley (Savage Streets, Return of the Living Dead), who played the scantily clad and doomed Denise; definitely my favorite actress in the film.  Another actress who put in a stellar performance was Lilyan Chauvin, as Mother Superior, who was pure evil and  wretched.  So convincing was her portrayal that you actually begin to root for Billy to get his revenge...I rediscovered this film in the 1990's while in high school; I made it a point to rent it one weekend.  My cousin and I ended up laughing like two goofy hyenas hopped up on the scent of a fresh kill, while watching the infamous sledding scene; in my opinion the true climax of the film.  The setup, the acting, and the effects truly are outstanding and are right up there with the earlier infamous scene of the mounted deer above the fireplace.Part 2Silent Night, Deadly Night: Part 2 must have been made on a $100... but what a well invested $100 it was.  What truly makes the movie is the over the top performance of Eric Freeman, playing the main character, Ricky.  Ricky is the younger brother of Billy and the last survivor of that doomed family from the first installment of Silent Night, Deadly Night.  Ricky is the size of a football player with eyebrows that have a mind of their own; when he gets angry they get set loose.  It is actually Eric Freeman's ridiculous performance that holds this mess together and uplifts the film from the first 30 minute re-hash of the first movie.  The man should proudly wear a crown with, Acting So Bad Its Good, emblazoned on it.Yes, the first 30 minutes plus is spent showing highlights of part one.  For someone who has seen the first one just prior to Part 2 or someone who has seen it as many times as I have it gets old fast.  On the other hand this could be a plus for those that have never seen the first film or need a refresher on what went down, but honestly... how could you forget every graphic detail from the first twisted piece of horror.Things really get cooking once Ricky is in his teens and executes his first kill of an abusive drunken piece of trash with a Jeep in a flashback scene.  Most of this film is shown as a flashback scene really.  Other highlights include impaling a thumb breaker (debt collector) on an umbrella (unique and instantly a classic); the punishing of an obnoxious theater heckler, Naughty; electrocution of a bleach blonde dude by car battery charger; and of course the most famous scene of all... Garbage Day!  Yes, Garbage Day is really what put this film on the map for those who were not familiar with its awesomeness already.  For those that have not seen this clip a million times on YouTube or on video I will not give it away, but I assure you it is good.The one real major downside to this film outside of its rehashed beginning is the lack of the actress Lilyan Chauvin, to reprise her role as Mother Superior.  No one viewing this, including Ricky, can truly get satisfaction with this imposter, Jean Miller, filling in as a wheelchair bound nun being on the receiving end of long overdue punishment.  Punish!  They even caked on some sort of disfigurement and discoloring to her face to trick or convince people into buying that it is the same woman.  Well it is not and that is how well Lilyan Chauvin played her role in the first film, you want to see her pay the piper in this one really bad.ConclusionThese movies definitely have had an impact on me and continued my interest into this genre of films (still hoping for Thanksgiving to come out).  To this day I still quote lines from these movies regularly and continue to pass on my enthusiastic devotion to these demented films to others of good taste.  Thankfully I was able to retire my VHS copies of parts 1 and 2 when they first re-released these B horror treasures to those dedicated fans.I will leave you with these wise words of wisdom I gained from watching this peculiar picture...Punishment is necessary, it is good, it is absolute...
summary: Punishment is Necessary, It is Good, It is Absolute

reviewText: As a young boy, Billy witnesses the murder of his parents by Santa Claus. He believes Santa punishes the bad and starts reliving the memories during his stay at a Catholic orphanage. He suffers abuse there at the hands of Mother Superior, gets a job at a toy store as a young man, then he goes on a demented killing spree as Santa.The DVD opens with the statement that this is "the most complete and unrated version," which is why there are scenes of varying quality. I find this strange because the DVD is rated "R", not Unrated. Also, there seems to be a rape scene missing. Some people say that Santa rapes the mother of the young boy, but this is never shown unless it was edited out. There is an attempted rape, but ends at the shirt ripping.This film, while not very gory, initially struck me as disturbing and then later, stupid. There are scenes of a young boy watching his parents being murdered by Santa, a preteen adolescent being beaten and tied up by the Mother Superior, and then cops shooting a deaf priest. The story starts out well showing the tortured boy and his evolution to a serial killer, but it goes down hill after that.There are also moments of unintentional humor like when the young boy grows up to be a muscle bound hunk in tight pants. There is a goofy montage of him working in a toy store and playing with Mr. Potato Head while a strange Christmas song plays.There were countless discrepancies, which made no sense, but help the audience laugh. For instance, child Billy has brown hair and brown eyes, orphanage Billy suddenly has blue eyes, and adult Billy magically grows blonde hair.The film quality was okay, but sound was spotty in some parts. The SFX was decent, but most death scenes were simply splashed blood. The director also sleazed it up in several parts. While there is plenty of boobage, the sex scenes were pretty boring and consisted of partners laying on top of each other motionless and confused.There is also a weird underlying message here about the importance of Christmas and Religion. Why would a Catholic orphanage tell children to write thank you notes to Santa for gifts, Isn't the typical religious protocol to pray? And there is an interesting comparison to a Hallmark holiday and a man-made religion.So who is bad here? The Naughty vs Nice/ Black vs White Simpleton Santa Claus? The unsympathetic, abusive, but organized Religion? Or the innocent, yet murderous Mentally Ill that slips through the cracks in our legal system?This film was banned 2 weeks after it's theatrical release due to an angry uproar and protests. What is strange is that parents claimed that "Christmas is sacred" and that is why this film is bad. I disagree. I thought the original idea was a great and the first f'ed 30 minutes were pretty good. If they wanted to complain about something, then why not the unethical treatment of children by authoritative, religious figures? Or how about the representation of nuns as domineering imbeciles? Or why not the sleazy way the women were depicted? Lee Harry, the director of the sequel, even states in commentary that it seems as though the women were only placed in the film to be abused by the men.DVD Extras: Scene Selection and Audio Interview with Director. "Santa's Stocking full of Outrage" features random letters of hate by critics, angry parents, and even Mickey Rooney who later starred in the Part 5!Bottom Line: I would recommend that horror fans check this out simply to see what the controversy is.Rating: 6/10Molly CelaschiSilent Night, Deadly Night Part 2 (1987)A Rip-off of the Original Silent Night, Deadly NightI immediately noticed this one has different writer (4 total which is not a good sign) and the director had changed.The sequel opens with Billy's younger brother Ricky in a psych ward being questioned. He miraculously recalls details of the murders despite not being there to witness them (!) and can completely recall his parents deaths even though he was an infant at the time!?!I guess the filmmakers got lazy because the first 40 minutes is stolen footage from the first film. What is even weirder, Ricky "recalls" scenes that he was not apart of. For example, one memory he recalls is of a cops' POV actions whom he had never met. That doesn't make any sense. And some of the stolen footage has new people cut into the scenes, making this super-weird. And How can a stranger get directing credit on a film that used someone else's footage?There are numerous inconsistencies as well. One is that multiple actors play Ricky and they do not look alike (same as Billy in the Original). The other flaw is that Ricky doesn't kill as Santa or near the holidays, so I guess they stole the movie title too.Other flaws: Ricky can hold someone in an electrical current and not get electrocuted himself. The same cop from the first one appears randomly on a street in this one even though it takes place in a different city. There are also 2 crew members clearly trying, but failing, to hide in the background of one scene. There are many more to list, but frankly, this is getting boring.There is one notable cool scene though. After a boyfriend attempts to rape his girlfriend, Ricky runs him over repeatedly in a jeep as she watches the spectacle. When he is finished, the girlfriend simply says, "Thank you" and walks off.Favorite Quote: "This is actually a good film" by Director Lee Harry at the end of the commentary.DVD Extras: Still Gallery, Trailer, and Commentary with the Writer Joseph Earle, Director Lee Harry, and Actor James Newman. The screenplay is also available on the DVD. I would look at this simply for laughs.According to the Commentary, the producers approached the Director and Writer to re-cut the original film as a sequel since it was pulled from the theaters. They decided to use the original footage and then write around it to try and create their own film. This seems especially ridiculous now since the Original was released on DVD and the sequel plays right after it.Bottom Line: This is a flashback, stolen footage piece of crap. It gets 1 point for the decent footage that was stolen, 1 point for the "Thank you rape victim", and  point for an attempt at other deaths later in the film.Rating: 2.5/10Molly Celaschi

reviewText: I recently purchased and watched these two controversial Christmas classics, three if you count the remake. I expected a lot worse, and I've seen some gross movies, let me tell you.The first one sets the stage for Billy's torment-he witnesses his parents raped and murdered by a Santa Claus killer, but that is just the start of his ordeal. Once at the orphanage, the iron fisted Mother Superior wouldn't get him the therapy he clearly needed, making every Christmas for him a nightmare.Part 2 was more about Billy's brother Ricky finishing what Billy started...although he seems to enjoy the carnage a lot more.I'm not sure the rest are worth a look, but did enjoy the remake.
summary: not sure about 3-5, these and the remake were decent.
Title: N/A

reviewText: With the plethora of slasher films that flooded the silver screen in the 1980s no movie angered more people than this gem, more specifically to the point of being pulled from theaters nationwide. The aggressive ad campaign showed during children's programming during the daytime hours was what did it in not content per se but since I brought it up this movie is not for the faint of heart and even by today's standards still packs a powerful punch.Little Billy Chapman witnesses the grizzly Christmas eve murder of his parents at the hands of jolly old Saint Nick and from that moment forward each Christmas is more trying and difficult for Billy along with having to live in an orphanage run by the sadistic Mother Superior who's idea of understanding and compassion is instant punishment by whippings and being tied to a bed which only leads to a recipe for a sure disaster later on. At 18 Billy takes a job at a department store and all is good and well until he has to dress as Santa Claus and that's where Billy comes full circle and what's been manifesting inside of him for years is released in all it's gory glory.If it's Christmas time and you need a break from all the syrupy and sugary movies and ads on tv or you're just plain tired of the commercialism itself this movie is the best "Screw you!" there is. I'm not going to oversell this movie because I know there's a lot more anti-Christmas movies released within the nearly 30 years since this movie was unleashed onto the world but the tone and no-holds-barred take-no-prisoners "I don't care about you or your stinking holiday" atmosphere can't be matched or beat by anything else in my opinion. This movie just doesn't care and revels in it.I can sit here and tell you how gory it is and how much nudity there is but the harsh atmosphere is the selling point of this movie. This is the movie that has no rules. Try this on for size, I've never seen a movie where a Santa Claus meets his demise in front of a group of angel-faced children not just once but twice and someone telling those same kids "there is no Santa Claus". The tension alone will have you on edge. Of course, there's some "wtf" moments because let's face it it is an 80s slasher but in all I think it's very well done and the acting is alright in my opinion. I can't say anymore.

reviewText: This film is awesome. I love it. When first released in 1984 it caused considerable controversy and was yanked from cinemas, nowadays i cant even find it in video stores. It has been banned in multiple places, due to the depictation of our beloved Santa Claus as a serial killer. Really that was so not neccesary as the fact that the movie is rated R means young children would not be able to view the film anyway, seriously people should get over it. Alot of people say the film is just crap and cheap, but i recon its really interesting and good, and the fact that it has a huge cult following show that im not alone in thinking this. Billy Chapman is a young kid riding with his parents of Xmas eve, they are visiting Billys catatonic grandfather. As Billys parents (nursing younger brother Ricky in their arms) discuss the Grandpas condition with the docter, Billy is left alone with the old man, suddenly Granpa spring to life and delivers Billy a chilling message "Xmas night is the scariest damn night of the year, you see Santa Claus, you better run............for your life!"Billy is now pertrified of Santa and when the family run into a physco dressed as Santa on the ride home (now nightime) his nightmare comes true. Santa brutally murders Billys parents as he watches............A few years later Billy and younger brother Ricky who both escaped the horrific night are in an orphanage run by nuns. Mainly Mother Superior, the head nun who is very strict on her upbringing of the children. We witness some of Mother Superiors cruel acts to bring Billy into line and then cut forward 10 years where Billy has grown into a HOT young man who is getting a job at the local toy store. From first apperance Billy seems like a normal, nice guy. We do learn that Billy is still traumatized by the events of what happened that night, and also he is still terrifyed of Santa. Come Christmas when Billy is asked to dress up as the one person he loathes, Santa Claus, he snaps. In a chilling scene Billy just completely snaps and embarks on a physcotic rampage to punish the 'naughty'. I really enjoyed this film and think that Robert Brian Wilson (Billy) did a great job, only being 16 when he played the role, he was excellent. I reccomend this film if you're a horror fan.
Title: N/A

reviewText: (Instead of reviewing a film you probably already know, I stick to DVD special features)Those Extras (Part 1):Commentary:  This was really laughable, but fits in with the theme of the disc.  The back cover says audio interview with the director...turns out it's actually a phone call to the guy!!  Once you get passed that, it's not halfway bad.  Runs for about thirty minutes and is fairly informative.  Unfortunately director Sellier comes off as gruff and bothered, one of those guys who you choose your words with carefully.  The only film related stuff he discusses is the infamous antlers moment and how cold it was.  Really would've liked to hear how the sledding scene was done.Misc:  A dopey "extra" called Santa's Stocking Stuffer of Outrage are what appear to be letters to the editors of several newspapers upon the film's release.  Anonymous cogs chiming in there two cents about the film's controversy.  I read three of them and moved on.Overall:  Well, at least this is on DVD now.  The transfer is beautiful, looks like the film came out last year.  For whatever reason the more violent scenes switch to a murkier, cheaper look.  I assume only the scenes approved by the ratings board were the ones mastered.  And depsite hype, this is the full-length cut that has been available for years on VHS.(Silent Night 2)Commentary:  Classic.  Better than the film itself!  Makers Harry and Earle, along with actor Newman pretty much lambast what's on screen.  At least they're honest with the quality of this joke of a film.  Though actor Newman comes off like a pervert/schmuck, he tires very quickly.  But they're laughter gets you through some unbearably amateurish and stupid scenes.Overall:  Well, can't say at least this is on DVD, as this sequel appalled me after the great part 1.  But it's included on part 1's disc so there's no avoiding it.  For some smiles and low-budget filmmaking stories pop it in.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I remember back in the good ol' days of 1984(I was 6-do the math), one night in December I was watching the six o'clock news when they started reporting on how Silent Night, Deadly Night opened locally, then was quickly removed coz of protesting(the scene with Billy giving a little girl a bloody knife as a present was a big factor in this).  Naturally I really wanted to see this  film.  People still don't seem to grasp the idea that if you raise alot of ruckus about a film, you give it promotion that even the best advertising agency couldn't dream of.  I mean, what's the big deal?  It's not like parents were gonna take their children to this film-only adults who buy tickets were gonna see it, so what's the fuss?  Anyway, SNDN is an interesting slasher flick in the sense that the killer isn't some faceless, mute juggernaut.  We actually stay with the killer throughout the whole film and see his deterioration into a slasher movie killer.  In an age where we have movies like Leprechaun, Uncle Sam, Jack Frost and Killer Klowns From Outer Space, one might think this film would be a little tongue in cheek.  It's not.  In fact, this movie takes itself quite seriously, and is actually pretty ugly and downright disturbing.  I was creeped out by the catholic orphanage Billy grows up in.  This movie is well worth seeing if you dig the golden age of slasher flicks and would appreciate a little twist on the formula.  Just don't raise your expectations too high.  Part 2 is a very bad film.  You know how dvds are equipped with the Scene Selection option?  You'll have to use this option to start the film halfway through if you don't want to watch(especially if you're having a SNDN back-to-back double feature) a condensed version of the first film.  Alot of horror sequels in the 70s and 80s did crap like this.  They have 45 minutes worth of an idea for a sequel and pad the other 45 minutes with footage from the first film.  This is a total insult to the audience.  Horror fans aren't quite as dumb as these people seem to think.  Part 2 could have been entertaining in a trashy way if it had focused entirely on Ricky.  In fact, Ricky is much more of a goofball and funny to watch than his brother Billy from Part 1.  The asking price is worth it for the first movie alone.  If you really have to watch Part 2, go ahead, but be ready to use your fast forward button......alot.
summary: Makes You Wanna Don Your Gay Apparel
Title: N/A

reviewText: Silent Night Deadly Night- After his parents are murdered a young tormented teenager goes on a murderous rampage dressed as Santa due to his stay at an orphanage where he was abused by the Mother Superior.Silent Night Deadly Night Part II- Ricky the brother of the killer in the first film talks to a psychiatrist about how he became a brutal killer after his brother died leading back to Mother Superior.In addition to what makes these horror flicks so intriguing is SILENT NIGHT DEADLY NIGHT 1 and 2 was another holiday-like horror flick inspired by John Carpenter's HALLOWEEN which was theatrically released in the Fall of 1978 and also inspired other holidays movie titles like NEW YEARS EVIL, APRIL FOOL'S DAY, MY BLOODY VALENTINE, and FRIDAY THE 13TH as well as the SILENT NIGHT, DEADLY NIGHT sagas.
summary: If Halloween had you jumping at every corner in the dark, if Nightmare On Elm Street gave you sleepless nights, dig this

reviewText: this movie is quite scary. i have the dvd of it, thanks anchor bay for releasing such a great dvd. anyway, dude this movie is messed up. the scariest part is in the beginning, when the kid's parents get killed. and the music in the very beginning, when the wreath is coming at you and you hear "santa's watching, santa's waiting, christmas eve is slowly fading" in that little kid's voice, it is so creepy. and there are many good death scenes, i won't give them away. it is hard to find a good christmas horror movie, but i will save you time by telling you, check out black christmas and this movie, forget the rest. you will be pissed off if you watch christmas evil, as a matter of fact, avoid troma movies at all costs, they are bast*rds and deserve to die, they disgrace the horror genre. anyway, check this movie out, replace "a muppet's christmas carol" or a miracle on 34th street" and watch this instead. one more thing, take some free advice. DO NOT watch this with your parents or any other adult. watch it by yourself in a dark room like i do, it makes it more scary anyway

reviewText: "B" horror/slash movies.  Just lots of great stuff in this movie.  Killings, T & A, laughable lines and lots more.  Plus...a big slap in the face to the religious god of the commercial holiday...Satan...I mean Santa...oh sorry, they are the same person.  Commercial Christmas is a joke, and the people who raise their kids to believe in a false and fake icon are a joke too.  In this movie, Satan, I mean Santa is gunned down twice in front of crying and shocked children.  GREAT!!  Plus Satan, I mean Santa goes around killing and "punishing" all who are naughty.  GREAT MOVIE.  Glad I bought it over three years ago before it went out of print.  Even Netflix doesn't (or won't) have a copy of this movie.  Too bad, it should be shown on national television every Christmas just like Jimmy Stewart.
